DataElement.preferredName: Patient Stage III Stage IV Clear Cell Ovarian Malignant Neoplasm Eligibility Determination Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator related to criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services based on Stage III or IV clear cell (cell with empty-appearing cytoplasm when viewed with a light microscope) ovarian (the female reproductive glands in which the ova (eggs) are formed) cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Stage III Stage IV Clear Cell Ovarian Malignant Neoplasm Eligibility Determination
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services based on Stage III or IV clear cell (cell with empty-appearing cytoplasm when viewed with a light microscope) ovarian (the female reproductive glands in which the ova (eggs) are formed) cancer.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Stage III Stage IV Clear Cell Ovarian Malignant Neoplasm Eligibility Determination
Property.preferredDefinition: Definition not available.:Definition not available.:A cell with empty-appearing cytoplasm when viewed with a light microscope.:Having to do with the ovaries, the female reproductive glands in which the ova (eggs) are formed. The ovaries are located in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Criteria to determine eligibility of patients for medical care programs and services.

Concepts.definition: Locally advanced cancer that has spread to nearby organs but not to distant anatomic sites.
Cancer that has spread to distant anatomic sites beyond its original site of growth.
A cell with empty-appearing cytoplasm when viewed with a light microscope.
Having to do with the ovaries, the female reproductive glands in which the ova (eggs) are formed. The ovaries are located in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The act of determining if a subject is suitable for enrollment in a study according specific protocol criteria and procedures.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

DataElementConcept.origin: GOG CRF:Gynecologic Oncology Group Case Report Form
